result.execSummary:
The defendant Andrew J Stuttgen was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Use a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime, a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.075(1r).
  • Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Defendant must pay all outstanding fees and court obligations including costs of supervision during the term of supervision.   If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.

Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent; specifically sex offender treatment and programming. Must register with Wisconsin Sex Offender Registry and follow all rules and regulations. No contact with anyone under the age of 18 without written approval of parents and agent. No use of Internet without agent approval. Not to be listed on Craigs list or any other social media site. Defendant must submit a DNA specimen, as required by law, and pay for the testing. Firearm warning given. Voting is prohibited until sentence is complete and civil rights have been restored.

Per RASO - defendant has been transferred to the prison system

Defendant Andrew J Stuttgen in court with attorney Kevin T. Noonan.  Defendant Andrew J Stuttgen in custody.  Robert Scott Repischak appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court Reporter: Patricia Schaefer. TRANSCRIPT FILED 05-06-2015/tk
The Court, as well as parties, have reviewed PSI. The Court has reviewed letters filed by Mr. Noonan. The State is in compliance with Ch. 950. No additions or corrections noted by the State. Defense puts correction on the record. The State recommends 5 yrs IC, 5 yrs ES on Ct 2 and on Ct 3- 3 yrs IC, 3 yrs ES consecutive.  The State asks conditions to include registering with SORP, sex offender treatment and no contact with minors. The State asks for the surcharge for 3 images. Defense is asking for the one image that deft plead to. Defense asks for 2-3 yrs IC/ES up to the Court.

BTC: Ct 2-Total sentence is 8 yrs WPS bifurcated as 5 yrs IC, 3 yrs ES/CFTS
         Ct 3-Total sentence is 5 yrs WPS bifurcated as 3 yrs IC, 2 yrs ES - conc with Ct 2

Conditions:
obey all rules and regs
costs
child porn surcharge for 3 images ($500.00 each)
DNA sample & costs
any counseling deemed approp by agent; specifically sex offender treatment and programming
Must register with SORP and follow all rules
no contact with anyone under the age of 18 w/o written approval of parents and agent
not to use internet without approval of agent
not to be listed on Craigs list or any other social media

FAW/vote

NOT eligible for CIP or ERP

State's offer and recommendation:  Plea to cts 2,3; d/ri balance.  Ct 2: 10 yrs> 5WPS & 5 ES.  Ct 3: 6 yrs> 3 WPS & 3 ES consecutive. Will not bring additional charges in Racine County or Dane County for addt'l child pornography found.

PLEA - guilty to both counts 2 and 3
Finding of guilt.  Court finds plea entered freely, knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently.

Plea is not going forward.  Defense filed memorandum re presumptive/mandatory sentencing length in statute 939.617.  Minimum sentence is no longer presumptive, but it now mandatory.
